comments:
There is a discrepancy between emf and uml layer assumptions. The MSLUtil is assuming that it can set the opposite end of the property to null (reference clean up, I assume may be to prevent potential memory leaks for instance), but uml layer in PropertyOperations assumes that the opposite end can not be null. 


stack trace :
java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.eclipse.uml2.uml.internal.operations.PropertyOperations.setOpposite(PropertyOperations.java:637)
at org.eclipse.uml2.uml.internal.impl.PropertyImpl.setOpposite(PropertyImpl.java:1135)
at org.eclipse.uml2.uml.internal.impl.PropertyImpl.eSet(PropertyImpl.java:1902)
at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.impl.BasicEObjectImpl.eSet(BasicEObjectImpl.java:605)
at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.core.internal.util.MSLUtil$TeardownAction.execute(MSLUtil.java:1185)
at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.core.internal.util.MSLUtil.teardownReferences(MSLUtil.java:1110)
at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.core.internal.util.MSLUtil.destroy(MSLUtil.java:226)
at org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.emf.core.util.EObjectUtil.destroy(EObjectUtil.java:187)
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 127082 ***
